learning_outcomes.description: Web Design (including accessibility): Analyse client goals and user research to design human-centred website structures and interfaces, and justify design decisions using UX/UI theory, accessibility standards, and ethical considerations. [THIS LEARNING OBJECTIVE CONTRIBUTES TO AQF9 RESEARCH FOR MASTERS PROGRAMS]

Web Development (HTML, CSS, JavaScript): Develop, implement, and evaluate responsive, accessible web pages using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, following contemporary front-end development practices and coding standards.

Tools for Design and Development: Employ industry-standard tools, including design software, development environments, version control, and verification tools, to support, improve, and document design and development processes.

Ethics in Web Design and Development: Identify, evaluate, and apply ethical principles to design and development decisions, demonstrating awareness of cultural, social, accessibility, and data-related impacts in professional web practice.

Responsible Use or Non-use of AI: Direct, evaluate, and validate decisions about AI-assisted contributions within design and development workflows, while maintaining human judgement, authorship, and academic or professional integrity.

assessments.task_description:
Use of AI is RESTRICTED in this Assessment Task

This assessment task is completed in person as an identity-verified progress check-in. Students are not permitted to use AI tools to generate answers or complete assessment requirements during the check-in.

However, because responsible and transparent use of AI tools is a core learning focus of the course, students may discuss, explain, or demonstrate prior use (or non-use) of AI tools as part of the guided professional conversation. This may include showing examples of how AI tools were used during their development process, explaining verification steps, or reflecting on limitations, risks, and decision-making.

In some cases, the teaching team member may invite a student to trial or explore an AI tool during the discussion for learning purposes. Any such use occurs under supervision and forms part of the assessment of professional judgement, not task completion.

Any unauthorised or deceptive use of AI tools during the check-in, including attempting to use AI to generate responses in place of explanation or reasoning, may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

What is this task?

The A1 Individual Progress Check-ins are structured one-on-one conversations with a member of the teaching team. Their purpose is to support your learning by reviewing your current progress, understanding, and decision-making at key points across the semester.

In each check-in, you will discuss the work you have completed to date and explain how and why you have made particular design and development decisions appropriate to the current stage of the course. These conversations are not only about what is working, but also about identifying challenges, reflecting on feedback, and planning next steps.

The check-ins are designed to help you develop professional habits of practice, including explaining your work clearly, exercising judgement about priorities and trade-offs, and progressively building independence over time.

How it is assessed

Across the semester, you will be assessed on four capabilities:

  • Professional reasoning and decision-making
  • Engagement in guided professional dialogue
  • Progressive development and professional autonomy
  • Responsible AI decision-making (or justified non-use)

 Each capability is assessed as:

  • Developing (Level 1), Competent (Level 2), or Advanced (Level 3).

Individual Progress Review A1.1 is timed to provide feedback on your progress prior to the Semester 1, 2026 Census (31 March, 2026).

Your final A1 grade is determined using a standards-based translation process that:

  • considers capability demonstrated across the semester, and
  • requires demonstration of minimum capability by the final check-in.

A detailed task sheet and grading criteria (including the standards-based translation process) for this assessment item is available in Blackboard in the Assessment Folder. It is important that you read both of these documents to understand all of the requirements of this assessment item.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The progress check-ins are in-person interactive oral assessment during your allocated applied class. These are not artefact submissions but identity-verified, time-bound professional conversations that require attendance, preparation, and active engagement at a specific point in the semester.

assessments.task_description:
Use of AI tools is PERMITTED in this assessment task.

This course explicitly develops students’ capability for responsible AI decision-making as part of professional web design and development practice. Students may choose to use AI tools, to limit or constrain their use, or to deliberately not use AI tools, provided that this decision is made thoughtfully, transparently, and in alignment with the course Responsible AI Decision-Making Capability Framework.

Where AI tools are used, students are expected to:

  • maintain human judgement, authorship, and decision-making authority,
  • critically evaluate and verify AI-generated outputs,
  • use AI tools to support learning and professional reasoning rather than replace them, and
  • transparently acknowledge and reflect on their use as required by the assessment task.

Responsible AI decision-making (including justified use, selective use, or deliberate non-use) forms part of the assessment expectations.

What is this task?

A2: Research and Proposal is an integrated assessment task where you investigate a design problem, analyse research findings, and develop a clear proposal for the website you will build in A3.

In this task, you will respond to the Connected Communities Initiative (CCI) client brief, using research to inform design requirements and proposing a website that meets the client’s goals, values, and constraints.

You will submit your work as a single, integrated website, where:

  • research activities and findings are documented,
  • insights are synthesised into design requirements and principles, and
  • a structured design proposal is presented and justified.

This task brings together research, design thinking, and early implementation in one coherent artefact.

What do I need to produce?

You will produce a deployed website that integrates research and proposal content. Specifically, you must submit:

  • A website deployed to UQCloud
  • A zip file containing the website source files
  • A GitHub repository, used to verify development progress if needed

Within the website, you will present:

  • your research process and key findings,
  • clear synthesis of those findings into design requirements,
  • a structured design proposal for your website,
  • partially implemented design components (e.g. UI elements demonstrated within style guide or proposal pages),
  • all research, synthesis, and proposal content must clearly demonstrate how your design responds to the CCI client brief, and
  • a reflection on your use or non-use of AI tools following the course requirements on Responsible AI Use.

Important: How this assessment is supported in class

The applied class activities for this course have been specifically designed to guide you through the completion of this assessment. These activities provide detailed guidance on what is expected and how to approach each component of the task.

If you are unable to attend a class, it is essential that you engage with the activities independently, as they form a core part of the learning required to complete this assessment successfully.

More information about the requirements for this assessment item are provided in an Assessment Task Sheet that will be available in the course Blackboard site.

What is this task?

A3: Website Development is your opportunity to turn your A2 decisions into a working website. You will implement the website structure, visual and interaction design, and key functionality using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, while integrating accessibility and ethical considerations in practice.

This task recognises that implementation reveals constraints. You may need to adapt parts of your A2 proposal, but you must justify any variations and show how your final build still aligns with your earlier reasoning.

What do I need to produce?

You will produce and submit a 7-page website deployed online (and committed to version control), implemented with component-based CSS and modular JavaScript, and incorporating required API interactions.

Your website must include the following pages:

  1. Landing page: index.html
  2. About page: a text-heavy page demonstrating strong layout, typography, readability, hierarchy, and scanning support
  3. Form page: includes a form that submits data to the course API using JavaScript
  4. API content page: retrieves content from the course API using JavaScript and dynamically renders it into the page with appropriate styling
  5. Extension page: an additional page of your choice that showcases your skills (e.g., a component demo page, interactive feature, accessibility enhancement, or design variation)
  6. Variations page: a page that details any variations from your A2 Research and Proposal to your final implementation
  7. AI Reflection page: a page that contains your reflection on AI use or non-use in accordance with the course requirements on Responsible AI Use.

In addition, across the website you must demonstrate:

  • Component-based CSS (reusable classes/components rather than page-specific styling only)
  • Modular JavaScript (separation of concerns; reusable functions/modules rather than one large script file)

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures | Weeks 1 to 13

Lectures in this course provide the conceptual foundations and theoretical frameworks for key topics in User Experience Design (UX), User Interface Design (UI), and Frontend Development (FED). Rather than functioning as extended presentations, lectures are designed as guided learning sessions that build understanding through preparation, discussion, and application.

Short preparatory videos or podcasts are generally provided before each lecture to introduce core concepts, terminology, and examples. These materials allow you to engage with the foundational content in advance, so that scheduled lecture time can be used for discussion, clarification, and short structured activities that deepen understanding.

Key features of lectures include:

  • Conceptual foundations: Lectures introduce and contextualise essential theories and principles, including usability, accessibility, ethical design, and interaction design concepts that underpin effective web design and development.
  • Active engagement: Scheduled lecture time is used for discussion, reflection, and small activities that help you interrogate ideas, connect theory to practice, and prepare for applied work.
  • Scaffolded learning: Lecture topics are carefully sequenced to build progressively across the semester, supporting increasing independence and complexity in applied and assessment work.
  • Industry relevance: Concepts and examples are grounded in contemporary professional practice, helping you develop transferable understanding rather than tool-specific knowledge.

Lectures provide the direction and framing for learning in the course, while deeper understanding is developed through Applied Classes, independent activities, and assessment tasks. Attendance is encouraged, and all preparatory materials, recordings, and resources are made available for review.

learning_activities.topic:
Applied Classes | Weeks 1 to 13

Applied Classes are the practical core of this course. They are structured, hands-on sessions where you apply lecture concepts directly to design and development work, supported by guided activities and feedback from the teaching team.

These classes are designed to reflect professional web design and development practice. Rather than following step-by-step instructions to produce a fixed outcome, you will engage in iterative design, coding, testing, debugging, and refinement. The focus is on developing understanding, judgement, and professional habits through practice.

Key features of Applied Classes include:

  • Applied learning: Activities are closely aligned with weekly lecture content, enabling you to put theory into practice immediately through design and development tasks.
  • Progressive expectations: Activities are sequenced across the semester to move from guided practice toward greater independence, mirroring the increasing expectations across assessment tasks.
  • Feedback and support: Applied Classes provide opportunities for formative feedback, discussion, and clarification, helping you identify issues early and refine your approach before assessment submission.
  • Assessment alignment" Applied Class activities are intentionally designed to support the completion of assessment tasks. Work completed in these sessions contributes directly to your progress in A1, A2, and A3.
  • Professional practice habits: You are encouraged to explain your decisions, respond to feedback, reflect on challenges, and make responsible choices about tools and workflows, including the use or non-use of AI tools.

To benefit fully from Applied Classes, you are expected to come prepared, actively engage with the activities, and use feedback to inform your ongoing work. If you are unable to attend a scheduled class, equivalent activities and resources will be provided, and you are responsible for completing them independently.
